abstract: We demonstrated widely tunable edge emitting single mode lasers based on the Vernier tuning principle using coupled cavities. We achieve a tuning range of 150nm with SMSR¿30dB with central wavelengths at 2100nm and 2300nm.

title: Wearables to Electronics: The Key Enabler for Personalized Healthcare
conferenceTitle: 2020 International Symposium on VLSI Design, Automation and Test (VLSI-DAT)
abstract: Wearable healthcare targets mitigate the impact of chronic diseases by providing continuous yet adequate monitoring and analysis of physiological signals. One way is to make electronics to be wearable, but it would not be pervasive enough; on the other hand, ifwe make the wearables (such as textile, hydrocolloid patches) to be integrated with electronics, then the pervasive healthcare becomes a reality. However, such a wearable environment is challenging for circuit designers due to unstable skin-electrode interface, huge mismatch, and static/dynamic offset. Wet and dry electrodes have very different electrical characteristic that needs to be addressed. Also, in wearable environment, trade-off between available resource and performance among the components (analog front-end and digital back-end) is of crucial. This talk will cover the design strategies of wearable healthcare sensor SoC. We will cover various circuit topologies and their key metrics to deal with such non-ideal wearable environments. Finally, an on-chip patient-specific epilepsy detection System-on-Chip (SoC) for wearables will be presented, which integrates all the components covered during the talk. The talk will conclude with interesting aspects and opportunities that lie ahead.

title: 3D Heterogeneous Integration Technology for Al System
conferenceTitle: 2020 International Symposium on VLSI Technology, Systems and Applications (VLSI-TSA)
abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. A complete record of the presentation was not made available for publication as part of the conference proceedings. Novel 3D heterogeneous integration technologies using self-assembly have been developed to achieve high-throughput and high-precision multichip-to-wafer stacking. Many known good dies (KGDs) are simultaneously self-assembled on a carrier wafer with a high alignment accuracy making use of liquid surface tension. The self-assembled dies on the carrier are simultaneously transferred to another wafer or interposer wafer by electrostatically de-bonding the carrier wafer after Cu nano-pillar hybrid bonding of self-assembled dies. These liquid surface tension technologies have been also applied for massively parallel self-assembling of known good dies (KGDs) on large-area substrates such as glass panels and rigid/flexible organic substrates. Three kinds of 3D heterogeneous integration technologies with large-area substrates, face-down self-assembly/direct stacking with via-middle TSVs, face-down self-assembly/direct stacking with via-last TSVs, and face-up self-assembly/transfer stacking with via-last TSVs, are demonstrated. In addition, a new TSV formation methodology based on advanced Directed Self-Assembly (DSA) with nanocomposites consisting of nano metal particles and block-co-polymers is proposed. Cylindrical nano-ordered structures with metal which act as nano-TSV are formed in Si deep holes through phase separation of polystyrene-block-poly methyl methacrylate polymers (PS-b-PMMA). These new self-assembly technologies have been applied to develop new heterogeneous 3D LSIs for Al including neuro LSIs. New cyclic neuro LSI will be presented.

title: Atomically-Precise Deposition and Etching of Metals using Electrochemistry - New Paradigms for Metallization of Integrated Circuits
conferenceTitle: 2020 International Symposium on VLSI Technology, Systems and Applications (VLSI-TSA)
abstract: Future nano-electronics circuits will critically require the ability to fabricate materials with precise, atomic-level control over structure and properties. Traditionally, fabrication of atomic-scale materials has been achieved through vapor-phase atomic layer deposition (ALD); however, this process has several drawbacks such as the use of unstable gas-phase precursors which may decompose yielding contaminated deposits. An alternative electrochemical approach, using liquid-phase precursors, called electrochemical atomic layer deposition (e-ALD) will be outlined in this talk. Through self-limiting surface electrochemistry coupled with electrode potential manipulation, electrochemical growth of metals (such as Cu and Co) one atomic layer at a time can be achieved. Attractive features of our electrochemical ALD approach include the use of benign, stable and low-cost precursors, high-purity deposits, versatility in terms of deposited materials and operating conditions, and scalability to large-area wafers. Extensions of the e-ALD process chemistry to achieve atomic layer etching (e-ALE) will also be demonstrated.
